Replace.Text: For this Age, +3 Combat Strength towards Naval Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
For this Age, gain +15% Gold[icon:YIELD_GOLD] at the cost of -10% Food[icon:YIELD_FOOD]
For this Age, +3 Combat Strength towards Air Units at the cost of -10% Influence[icon:YIELD_DIPLOMACY]
For this Age, gain +15% Gold[icon:YIELD_GOLD] at the cost of -10% Food[icon:YIELD_FOOD]
Legend Unlock.[n]+25% [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold from [icon:TRADE_INCOME] Trade Income and [icon:UNIT_TREASURE_FLEET] Treasure Convoys.
Legend Unlock. +5 [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength for all Units against [icon:CITY_FORTIFIED] Fortified Districts.

Fear is a weapon. It preceded the Mongol hordes, causing cities to surrender even at the rumor of their approach, and it was vital to Blackbeard’s campaign of piracy across the Caribbean. As his plain red "bloody flag" or his “death’s head flag,” black with a skull (not a devil skeleton piercing a heart as commonly claimed), ran up the mast, ships would give up their cargo rather than face what they feared. The tall, outlandishly-dressed pirate would famously wear lit fuses in his beard – the better to intimidate his foes. But this is Blackbeard, the pirate of imagination, rather than Edward Teach, the man.

Teach – occasionally written “Thatch” – appears in the historical record in New Providence, the base of the short-lived Republic of Pirates in the Caribbean. Before this is only speculation: that he was, for instance, a privateer during Queen Anne’s War (fought between France and Spain over control of North America). Blackbeard served in the short-lived Republic of Pirates under the command of Benjamin Hornigold and quickly acquired conquests and fame – notably taking over the crew of “Gentleman” Stede Bonnet, his former collaborator, when that captain’s authority was questioned.

But the Republic was to falter under pressures both internal and external. As it collapsed, Teach set out on his own, capturing a French vessel and renaming it the Queen Anne’s Revenge, and from its decks he menaced European trade across the New World. In perhaps his most famous exploit, he blockaded Charles Town, in what is now the state of South Carolina, and held its citizens for ransom.

Despite his reputation, Teach could be gracious in conquest, and rarely engaged in the kind of cutlass-swinging deck combat which he became famous for. His captives were well-treated, and he at times showed a great deal of mercy – the threat of violence, and not necessarily violence itself, was his most deadly weapon.

Blackbeard attempted to retire and started a more peaceful life in North Carolina, but his respite lasted only a few months. Though he had secured a royal pardon, he took the Queen Anne’s Revenge out to patrol the Atlantic waters again. On the morning of November 22, 1718, he was attacked and killed by Robert Maynard, a lieutenant in the British Royal Navy. Blackbeard’s head was, allegedly, hung from the bowsprit of Maynard’s flagship, and, North Carolina folklore attests, his ghosts still stalks the Outer Banks.
Fix me deadlights, matey. We aim for plunder and profit, and give naught to king nor God.
Hark ye to the Admiral of the Black, the scourge of the seven seas - Edward Teach, Blackbeard in the flesh.
Hark ye to the Admiral of the Black, the scourge of the seven seas - Edward Teach, Blackbeard in the flesh.
Hark ye to the Admiral of the Black, the scourge of the seven seas - Edward Teach, Blackbeard in the flesh.
Bring a spring on her cable, hearties! There's blood to be had.
Damnation seize my soul if I give you quarter or take any from ye!
Aye, ye've sunk me. 'Tween the Devil and Davey Jones, there's thee.

All Naval Units gain the [icon:UNIT_CAUTION] Pirate Ability, allowing them to cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] Plunder Trade Routes from non-Allied Civilizations, and attack Naval Units of non-Allied Civilizations without declaring [icon:WAR] War. Defeating any Naval Unit with your own Naval Units provides [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold equal to 50% of its [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] Combat Strength and captures that Unit under your control. +1 Gold Maintenance for Naval Units.

[BLIST][LI]All Naval Units gain the [icon:UNIT_CAUTION] [B]Pirate Ability[/B], allowing them to cross borders of other Civilizations, [icon:Action_Pillage] [B]Plunder Trade Routes[/B] from non-Allied Civilizations, and attack Naval Units of non-Allied Civilizations [B]without declaring [icon:WAR] War[/B].[LI]Defeating any Naval Unit with your own Naval Units provides [B][icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold[/B] equal to 50% of its [icon:NAR_REW_COMBAT] [B]Combat Strength[/B] and captures that Unit under your control. [LI][B]+1 [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold [/B]Maintenance for [B]Naval Units[/B].[/LIST]
Likes leaders that build Naval Units. Dislikes leaders that neglect to build Naval Units.

Admiral of the Black, you know well that it is the name, not the gun, that is the deadliest bullet, and though you were born Edward Teach, it is the name Blackbeard that caused sailors to quail. Cast off now, as there are ships and caravans alike heavy with plunder. Prepare the Queen Anne’s Revenge again for war - there’s booty to be had.
Figurehead of the Queen Anne's Revenge
Defeating any Naval Unit grants [icon:YIELD_GOLD] Gold equal to 25% of its Combat Strength.
As Edward Teach, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Pax Imperatoria Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Silk Roads Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Silk Roads Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Silk Roads Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Non Sufficit Orbis Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Non Sufficit Orbis Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Non Sufficit Orbis Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Treasure Fleet Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Treasure Fleet Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Treasure Fleet Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Ideology Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Ideology Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Ideology Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Railroad Tycoon Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Railroad Tycoon Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Railroad Tycoon Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Antiquity Age.
As Edward Teach, finish the Antiquity Age twice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Antiquity Age thrice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Exploration Age.
As Edward Teach, finish the Exploration Age twice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Exploration Age thrice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Modern Age.
As Edward Teach, finish the Modern Age twice.
As Edward Teach, finish the Modern Age thrice.
As Edward Teach, reach at least 1 Legacy Path Milestone.
As Edward Teach, reach at least 2 Legacy Path Milestones.
As Edward Teach, reach at least 3 Legacy Path Milestones.
As Edward Teach, complete the Great Library Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Great Library Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Great Library Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Enlightenment Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Space Race Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Space Race Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Space Race Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Wonders of the Ancient World Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Wonders of the Ancient World Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Wonders of the Ancient World Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Toshakhana Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Toshakhana Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Toshakhana Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Geographic Society Legacy Path.
As Edward Teach, complete the Geographic Society Legacy Path twice.
As Edward Teach, complete the Geographic Society Legacy Path thrice.
As Edward Teach, complete 2 Legacy Paths in a single Antiquity Age.
As Edward Teach, complete 2 Legacy Paths in a single Exploration Age.
As Edward Teach, complete 2 Legacy Paths in a single Modern Age.
As Edward Teach in Antiquity, complete a quest to unlock the sea.
As Edward Teach in Antiquity, complete a quest to settle a disagreement.
As Edward Teach in Exploration, complete a quest to set alight fuses.
As Edward Teach in Exploration, complete a quest to enforce the Pirate Code.
As Edward Teach in Modern, complete a quest to establish an underwater threat.
As Edward Teach in Modern, complete a quest to impose the law of the sea.
Contains a new leader, Edward Teach.

The wind off the water carries the sting of salt and the voices of sea-birds as the singer steps into the square. He gazes at Blackbeard’s captains, where they wait to hear what will be sung. Cutlasses are sharp, and fingers are itchy.
“What do ye do with a drunken sailor?”
The grog seems to have slaked their thirst for other, redder things.
A fell light shines in Teach’s captains’ eyes.
The captains head to the docks, awaiting their profits.
Dhows slide through Aksumite waters, even when they are laden with riches, and they slide equally well past the grasp of Blackbeard’s corsairs. Surely this can be corrected.
“Masters of the sea,” Aksum is not. Not anymore.
The Admiral of the Black is gracious. Aksum may go where it will.

Sailing near home ports, where one can find a sheltered cove if the sky turns black and the water steely, all but the most incompetent captain is assured of reaching safe harbor. But on long voyages, there is more uncertainty – a storm and a hostile coast have wrecked many a vessel.
Provide captains with funds to bribe local harbormasters.
Direct weather-workers to tie the winds into knots.
Start a betting pool on who will sink.

Blackbeard’s pirates have made a friend – a young nobleman claiming to be of Venus’ line, captured in battle. His compatriots have offered a small sum of money for his release – the man convinces them to double it. “When you next see me,” he says with a smile, “I’ll kill you all.”
A good joke! Take the money.
A good joke! Throw him to the sea.
Sailors whisper as Edward Teach passes: “Hark ye to yon beard. What’s ‘e got under thar, ye wot?”
“I told ye,” says the first sailor, “they galleys be for bullion an’ blood.”
“See now,” says the second sailor, “he rubs his chin an’ gold falls out.”
“Land-lubbers,” Blackbeard observes to a captain, “hark to the sea nowt. They see a wall, an’ we see a door in the sea, see? An’ here,” he gestures to the ship, “be the key to yon door.”
The sea is an open door, as Blackbeard predicted. Through that door come blades and fire.

Aboard the merchant ship, just having returned from a long voyage, an argument breaks out between the first mate and captain. “I’ll be scuppered!” the mutineer gasps, “ye bilge-rat! To serve years now on this boat and this be my share?” Edward Teach steps in.
“Aye, bucko. Ye’ll get what ye deserve.” The captain backs down.
Living standards are better now, but the question of sailors and their wages remains. A code, perhaps, is in order.
“Aye, bucko. Ye’ll get what ye deserve.” A splash.

With a shuddering crunch, the enemy ship lurches. Water rushes into the hold, and Blackbeard’s sailors leap aboard to salvage what they can before it all goes to the deep. Not everything can be saved.
Let its fate be a lesson.

Among Blackbeard’s captains, one has risen to prominence. It is said that they can command the waves and fish, that the skies darken above their ship, and that they can shatter masts and timbers with a glance.
This is a monarch of the seas. Give them all that they desire.
Commanders are commanders, equal under the black flag.
Blackbeard is captain, not some upstart.
{1_reward} and all current Fleet Commanders gain a Level, but lose highest Level Fleet Commander.
The defeated captain kneels on the deck of his former ship. Gunsmoke hangs heavy in the sea air. “Release us!” he pleads, “there will be something in it for you…” His gaze moves upward, “personally…”
Steal {1_SUBJECT_CIVILIZATION_ADJ} Map (explore all tiles they have explored).
“Ye’ll tell us where to find more of ye.”
“Take it up with the devil.” There is a splash.
Majapahit navies have perfected the swivel-gun, a deck-mounted cannon that does not require captains to line up broadside to their foes. A nice prize, should one capture it.

It is a dance atop the waves. The pirate ship turns about, drags their anchor, furls and unfurls their sail. The cetbang’s swivel-gun tracks their every move… until a stray shot sends it to the sharks.
Broadsides it will be. Broadsides it will always be.

Production quotas and personnel lists, wage-books and land-deeds – these are things Edward Teach finds useless. As the captured ship lays bare its hold, he wonders if one could prosper simply by taking the spoils at gunpoint.
The gun-sight, not the ledger, shall be Blackbeard’s new strategy.
What is yours is mine, and what’s mine is mine.
Promise not to do it again.

“I’ll be a bilge-rat yet. Ye’ve gone an’ made me a god,” Blackbeard mutters at the doors of the temple. “Wood-scrivener!” he shouts, “Go an’ add some tentacles on yon beard, would ye?” The wood-carver tries to ignore the fact that his leader pronounces the word to rhyme with “cheese.”
Extra Relic Slot on the Palace.
Extra Relic Slot on the Palace and {1_reward}, but {2_reward}.

At the news of his crew’s circling of the world, Blackbeard pours grog for all. A drunken foreigner wades into the surf and the pirate calls out: “Ahoy! Ye scurvy dog, what do ye in me lake? All the sea’s mine, savvy?”
Make it policy. The sea is Blackbeard’s.
{1_reward} Naval Units, but -20 Relationship with all Civilizations.

The anchor clanks as it is drawn aboard. The ship groans as it begins to move out of its slip. Edward Teach scans the horizon, and a fresh breeze sets his black beard dancing around his ears. “Where sail we?” his first mate asks.

A satirical play has gained popularity, depicting Blackbeard as an inflated, pompous charlatan. The playwrights and performers have – of course – been keel-hauled, but Blackbeard worries about his image.
Pick a fight with someone big.
Audacity has its admirers. A pirate fleet joins the cause.
Defeat 3 Units without being at War with that Civilization (Units from Independents Powers or City-States do not count).
In a dirty looking-glass, Blackbeard ties ribbons and braids into his namesake. It is an impressive beard. But does it strike fear?
Fuses – lit fuses – should do the trick.
The beard now sizzles and smokes. Blackbeard’s enemies now quiver and shake.

On a ship, there is the bosun and the purser, the sailing master and the cook, and the pirate code fixes each of them in their role. Edward Teach begins to see similarities in his cities: the smith, the scribe, the banker, the weaver.
Draft a Pirate Code for the land.
Each urban quarter has its captain, each market its purser. Cities are but ships on land.
Let the pirates have their special status.

On deck, the whips crack again and again – forty lashes, sparing one. Such is the penalty under the Pirate Code for smoking one’s pipe below decks without a lid. Or dry-firing a weapon. Or lighting an uncovered candle. Or playing music on a Sunday.
Aye, these be the Articles of Agreement.
The Pirate Code is set, and all agree to it.
One of Blackbeard’s admirals shows a surprising fondness for writing – forgeries and lascivious poems, mostly. But in the hold of his latest nautical prize, they spy an opportunity.
Forge hostile war plans against Blackbeard’s navy.
+1 War Support on all wars, but {1_reward}.

An admiral has grown melancholic after his fifth pint of grog, and the conversation turns towards foreign navies. “Avast!” he cries, “t’aren’t a ship afloat can stand against ‘em.” Blackbeard’s eyes glint: “We’ll see on that, bucko.”
The enemy standards, fire-scarred and crumpled, are tossed to Blackbeard’s feet. “Mount ‘em in the privy,” he orders.

The Admiralty headquarters, draped in black and cross-bones, is the home of a grisly gallery of Blackbeard’s triumphs over the ages. “The seas are mine,” the gallery says without saying. Blackbeard considers which of these to feature over the doorway.
Mount the painted eyes of the dhow.
Mount the swivel-gun of the cetbang.
Mount the tattered standard of the Mikasa.
Blackbeard’s captains call him “the louse-bite,” “the sea-blight,” or a host of unprintable things – the most feared captain that stood against Edward Teach’s navy. And here he is, a prisoner.

The black flag of Blackbeard used to send crews to flight the minute it crested the horizon. But his new ships offer yet another level of intimidation by being not seen, but unseen, lurking beneath the surface.
The black flag flies in the deep. The crashing surf whispers “death.” Davey Jones collects those who dare to sail on Blackbeard’s sea. Hark ye to the Admiral of the Black.

One of Edward Teach’s merchant vessels has been impounded by foreign authorities. Whether or not it was smuggling seems to be beside the point – the trading companies demand that a law of the sea, written and administered by Teach himself, be imposed.
The sea shall have its Admiral.
All who sail on the seas pay their respects to Edward Teach, the ruler of all that seethes and foams. Hark ye to the Admiral of the Blue.

Some Units have the [icon:UNIT_CAUTION] [b]Pirate [/b]ability, such as Naval Units commanded by {LOC_LEADER_EDWARD_TEACH_NAME}. With Pirating, Units can attack other Naval Units that they are not at War with. Be on the lookout for [icon:UNIT_CAUTION] [b]Pirates[/b]: you may need to fight back.
As Edward Teach, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Naval Units, -10% Influence
As Edward Teach, access a new Exploration Legacy Card:[n] +15% Gold, -10% Food
As Edward Teach, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +3 Combat Strength towards Air Units, -10% Influence
As Edward Teach, access a new Modern Legacy Card:[n] +15% Gold, -10% Food
+5 Combat Strength for all Units against Districts.
+25% Gold from Trade and Treasure Convoys.
[B]Edward Teach[/B] was from the same continent as [B]France[/B].
